characters.description: The host of the extravagant parties, he is a mysterious figure whom many guests have never met. He is later revealed to be a veteran of the First Division during the war and lives in a mansion on Long Island.
A friend of the narrator, she is a professional golfer who lost in the finals of a tournament. She is cynical and somewhat detached, and is the one who introduces the narrator to Gatsby.

The narrator lives next door to Gatsby and receives a formal invitation to one of his parties. He is a veteran of the Twenty-eighth Infantry during the war and is curious about Gatsby's identity and background.

One of the girls in yellow dresses, she recounts a story of Gatsby replacing her torn gown with an expensive new one. She speculates about Gatsby's past, suggesting he may have been a German spy or killed a man.
One of the twins in yellow dresses, she met Jordan Baker at a previous party. She shares rumors about Gatsby's past, suggesting he may have killed a man.
One of the three men at the table with the girls in yellow, Jordan, and the narrator. They listen eagerly to the rumors about Gatsby.
Jordan's escort, he is persistent and cynical, and believes Jordan will eventually yield to him. He is later found in an obstetrical conversation with two chorus girls.
A stout, middle-aged, drunk man with enormous spectacles found in Gatsby's library. He is amazed to discover that Gatsby's books are real.
The woman who brought the owl-eyed man to Gatsby's party. The owl-eyed man met her somewhere the previous night.
The leader of the orchestra at Gatsby's party, he announces the performance of "Vladmir Tostoff's Jazz History of the World!". He smiles with jovial condescension.
The composer of "Vladmir Tostoff's Jazz History of the World!", a piece that attracted much attention at Carnegie Hall.
Gatsby's butler, he delivers the invitation to Jordan Baker to speak with Gatsby alone. He also informs Gatsby that Chicago is calling him on the wire.
A tall, red-haired young lady from a famous chorus, she sings and weeps in Gatsby's long, many-windowed room. She is heavily intoxicated with champagne.
They perform a baby act in costume at the party.
Referenced as the dancer on the platform is mistaken as her understudy.
Attend Gatsby's parties.
Eight servants maintain Gatsby's estate.
Provide food and decorations for Gatsby's parties.
Swim at Gatsby's beach.
Drive to Gatsby's parties.
Dot Gatsby's parties, looking hungry and selling something.
Sings in Italian at the party.
Sings in jazz at the party.
Met the narrator in the First Division during the war.
Sits at a table with the narrator, Jordan, and Gatsby, and laughs uncontrollably.
